Inference: Water usage dropping sharply during rain detections and weather-based irrigation reductions indicates strong rainfall replacement
Description: The system correctly reduces irrigation when rainfall events occur and watering is no longer needed.
short rationale: Rain replaces irrigation; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage remaining high during rain detections despite weather-based reductions indicates misalignment or delayed irrigation shutdown
Description: The system detects rain but continues watering, suggesting override settings or slow response.
short rationale: Highlights misaligned shutdown despite rain.

Inference: Water usage rising during long rain-detection gaps while weather logs show irrigation increases indicates drought-recovery irrigation behavior
Description: Extended dry periods trigger both automatic irrigation boosts and higher water usage.
short rationale: Dry-gap compensation; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage falling during long rain-detection gaps while weather logs show reductions indicates forecast-based water conservation
Description: The system may expect rain and reduce irrigation even before rainfall occurs, conserving water.
short rationale: Forecast-based cutbacks; modest operational exposure.

Inference: Water usage remaining low during frequent rain detections and weather-based reductions indicates wet-season irrigation suppression
Description: Both rainfall events and system logic continually minimize irrigation in wet conditions.
short rationale: Wet-season suppression; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising despite frequent rain detections and weather-based reductions suggests insufficient rainfall intensity
Description: Rain signals occur, but rainfall volume is too low to reduce irrigation needs.
short rationale: Insufficient rain prompting use; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling to near-zero during repeated rain detections and weather-based reductions indicates exclusive rainfall hydration
Description: Natural rainfall provides all required moisture, eliminating irrigation demand.
short rationale: Rain-only hydration; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases with high water usage during long dry periods with no rain detections indicate strong environmental drying conditions
Description: The system compensates aggressively for extended rainfall absence.
short rationale: Aggressive compensation during dryness; low privacy impact.

Inference: Weather-based reductions with low water usage during rain detections indicate effective real-time rainfall adaptation
Description: Rainfall instantly reduces irrigation activity and water output.
short rationale: Effective rain adaptation; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during rain gaps with stable low water usage indicates configuration limiting irrigation scaling
Description: The system requests more irrigation, but output remains capped or restricted.
short rationale: Potential cap/limitation despite increase commands.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions without rain detections but with decreasing water usage indicate humidity-driven or cloud-coverâ€“driven adjustments
Description: The system reduces irrigation even in the absence of rain due to environmental moisture cues.
short rationale: Non-rain moisture cues reducing use; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising before rain detections while weather logs show increases may indicate forecast-driven pre-watering
Description: The system boosts irrigation in anticipation of dryness before rainfall begins.
short rationale: Pre-watering ahead of expected rain; modest operational detail.

Inference: Water usage dropping before rain detections while weather logs show reductions indicates forecast-driven irrigation minimization
Description: Irrigation is reduced because expected rainfall is predicted soon.
short rationale: Pre-rain minimization; low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based reductions with stable water usage during rain detections indicate irrigation system timing delays
Description: The system has recognized rainfall but the physical irrigation cycle has not yet shut off fully.
short rationale: Delay between logic and actual shutoff.

Inference: Weather-based increases with rising water usage during periods of intermittent rain detections indicate rainfall insufficient to maintain soil moisture
Description: Frequent but weak rainfall fails to prevent irrigation demand increases.
short rationale: Weak/intermittent rain prompting irrigation; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling gradually after rain detections even without additional weather-based reductions indicates soil saturation effects
Description: Rainfall increases soil moisture enough to naturally lower irrigation need.
short rationale: Saturation lowering use; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage stabilizing at a low level during alternating rain detections and weather reductions suggests a balanced mixed-wet climatic period
Description: Frequent wet conditions keep irrigation volume consistently low.
short rationale: Mixed-wet period keeps usage low; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage fluctuating strongly during alternating rain detections and weather increases suggests unstable, intermittent storm patterns
Description: Irrigation has to adapt continuously to unpredictable rainfall behavior.
short rationale: Unstable storms forcing frequent adjustment; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising sharply after multiple rain detections when weather logs show increases indicates rapid post-rain evaporation or soil drying
Description: Moisture from rainfall dissipates quickly, forcing irrigation to scale upward.
short rationale: Post-rain drying drives high use; moderate concern.

Inference: Water usage dropping sharply after multiple rain detections when weather logs show reductions indicates cumulative rainfall saturation
Description: Soil stays moist long after rain events, reducing irrigation demand.
short rationale: Cumulative saturation reduces need; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising despite weather-based reductions and absence of rain detections indicates predictive logic failing to match actual dryness
Description: The system expects sufficient moisture, but conditions remain dry.
short rationale: Forecast mismatch leading to dryness.

Inference: Water usage falling despite weather-based increases and absence of rain detections suggests user intervention or system override
Description: Manual settings or hardware limitations prevent irrigation scaling.
short rationale: User/override or failure blocking commanded increases.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases with rapidly rising water usage during extended rain-detection gaps indicate early-stage drought formation
Description: Rainfall absence forces irrigation demand up before critical dryness.
short rationale: Early drought compensation; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions with rapidly falling water usage during consecutive rain detections indicate high-intensity rain events
Description: Heavy rainfall makes irrigation unnecessary across cycles.
short rationale: High-intensity rain suppresses use; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Stable water usage during volatile weather logs and inconsistent rain detections indicates irrigation insensitivity to environmental variation
Description: System may be configured with fixed watering schedules.
short rationale: Insensitivity due to fixed scheduling; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage rising during nighttime rain detections when weather logs show increases indicates mistimed irrigation schedules
Description: Irrigation cycles overlap with rainfall during times when watering should be minimized.
short rationale: Mistimed night watering despite rain.

Inference: Water usage dropping during nighttime rain detections when weather logs show reductions indicates ideal irrigation suppression
Description: The system avoids unnecessary watering during rain and low-evaporation nighttime conditions.
short rationale: Correct night suppression; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising during high-temperature rain detections while weather logs increase indicates warm-season storm incompetence
Description: Rainfall fails to lower irrigation demand due to heat-driven moisture loss.
short rationale: Heat overrides storm moisture; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling during low-temperature rain detections while weather logs reduce indicates efficient cold-season water saving
Description: Cool rain events allow deep moisture retention, reducing irrigation requirement.
short rationale: Efficient cold-season saving; very low sensitivity.
